skill.name: scvi-tools
skill.description: This skill should be used when working with single-cell omics data analysis using scvi-tools, including scRNA-seq, scATAC-seq, CITE-seq, spatial transcriptomics, and other single-cell modalities. Use this skill for probabilistic modeling, batch correction, dimensionality reduction, differential expression, cell type annotation, multimodal integration, and spatial analysis tasks.
skill.summary: This skill should be used when working with single-cell omics data analysis using scvi-tools, includ...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing markdown educational content about scvi-tools library. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or file system access. All 392 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES: markdown backticks misidentified as shell commands, mathematical notation (KL divergence) misidentified as weak crypto, git hashes misidentified as C2 keywords, and documentation URLs misidentified as malicious endpoints.

content.user_title: Analyze single-cell omics data with scvi-tools
content.value_statement: Single-cell genomics analysis requires specialized probabilistic models for dimensionality reduction, batch correction, and integration across diverse modalities. scvi-tools provides deep generative models built on PyTorch for comprehensive single-cell data analysis.
actual_capabilities: Perform unsupervised dimensionality reduction and batch correction using scVI model
Conduct semi-supervised cell type annotation with scANVI and transfer learning
Integrate multimodal data including CITE-seq, ATAC-seq, and spatial transcriptomics
Execute differential expression analysis with uncertainty quantification
Train deep generative models on single-cell count data
Apply spatial deconvolution to map cell types to spatial locations
limitations: Requires raw count data in AnnData format - normalized data not suitable
GPU recommended for large datasets but works on CPU with reduced performance
Models require sufficient cell counts per group for stable estimates
Limited to Python environment with scvi-tools and scanpy dependencies

use_cases.title: Multi-batch scRNA-seq integration
use_cases.description: Integrate multiple single-cell datasets across sequencing batches while preserving biological variation.

use_cases.title: Cell type annotation transfer
use_cases.description: Transfer cell type labels from annotated reference datasets to new query datasets using semi-supervised learning.

use_cases.title: Spatial deconvolution analysis
use_cases.description: Map cell type proportions to spatial transcriptomics data to understand tissue architecture.

prompt_templates.title: Basic scVI workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up and train an scVI model on my single-cell RNA-seq data for dimensionality reduction and batch correction. Use raw counts, register batch covariates, and extract latent representations.

prompt_templates.title: Cell type annotation
prompt_templates.prompt: Use scANVI to annotate my single-cell dataset. Some cells have labels in the cell_type column. Train to predict labels for unlabeled cells with probabilities.

prompt_templates.title: Differential expression
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform differential expression analysis between two cell populations using my trained scVI model with Bayesian hypothesis testing and delta=0.25 threshold.

prompt_templates.title: Reference mapping
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply scArches to map my query dataset to a pretrained scVI reference model for transfer learning.

output_examples.input: Train scVI on my scRNA-seq data with batch correction
output: - Setup: Register AnnData with batch_key='sample' and layer='counts'
- Train: 400 epochs with early stopping on validation loss
- Extract: Latent representation stored in adata.obsm['X_scVI']
- Output: Batch-corrected embeddings ready for clustering and UMAP visualization

output_examples.input: Find differentially expressed genes between cell types
output: - Use differential_expression() method on trained model
- Specify groupby column and comparison groups
- Returns DataFrame with Bayes factors and log fold changes
- Filter by bayes_factor threshold for significant genes

output_examples.input: Integrate spatial transcriptomics with single-cell reference
output: - Load reference single-cell data with cell type annotations
- Train DestVI model on reference for spatial deconvolution
- Fit model to spatial transcriptomics counts
- Output: Cell type proportions per spatial spot location

best_practices: Always use raw unnormalized count data for scvi-tools models
Filter low-quality cells and genes before training to improve performance
Register all known technical covariates in setup_anndata call
Save trained models to avoid retraining on the same data
anti_patterns: Using log-normalized data instead of raw counts for model input
Training without specifying batch_key when integrating multiple samples
Applying scVI embeddings directly without validating batch correction
Ignoring model training metrics and convergence indicators

faq.question: What data formats does scvi-tools support?
faq.answer: scvi-tools works with AnnData objects containing raw count matrices. Supports 10x matrices, loom files, and h5ad format through scanpy.

faq.question: How much RAM do I need for scvi-tools?
faq.answer: Memory usage scales with cells and genes. Start with 16GB RAM for datasets under 50k cells. Large datasets may require 64GB or more.

faq.question: Can scvi-tools integrate with Seurat or Scanpy?
faq.answer: Yes, scvi-tools outputs store results in AnnData objects compatible with scanpy. Use scanpy for clustering, visualization, and downstream analysis.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using scvi-tools?
faq.answer: scvi-tools processes data locally in your Python environment. No data leaves your machine. Models train offline without external network calls.

faq.question: Why is my model not converging?
faq.answer: Check that input data contains raw counts not normalized. Verify no NaN values exist. Reduce learning rate or increase epochs if needed.

faq.question: How does scvi-tools compare to Seurat integration?
faq.answer: scvi-tools provides probabilistic modeling with uncertainty quantification while Seurat uses anchor-based alignment methods.
